stem: Which of the following nursing actions is MOST important to implement FIRST for a patient experiencing autonomic dysreflexia?

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed to 45 degrees helps to immediately lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling and reducing cerebral perfusion. This is the fastest and easiest intervention to implement and provides immediate benefit.

mnemonic.name: SIT UP
mnemonic.description: SIT UP = Symptoms Identify Trigger, Unclog (catheter/bowel), Position upright

rationale.incorrect: Administering Hydralazine is important, but only after initial interventions to reduce blood pressure are implemented. Finding and removing the cause is the priority. Administering oxygen is not indicated unless the patient is hypoxic.

questionTrap.whyMistake: Medication is a crucial part of the treatment, but addressing the cause and lowering blood pressure via position change are the initial steps.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Students often prioritize medication administration before addressing the underlying cause and positioning the patient.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention.
The most common cause of autonomic dysreflexia is bladder distension.
Other triggers include bowel impaction, pressure ulcers, and restrictive clothing.
Untreated autonomic dysreflexia can lead to stroke, seizure, and death.

itemContext.sbar: 14:00: S: Patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of T6 spinal cord injury, admitted for a routine check-up. 14:15: B: Patient has a history of recurrent UTIs and manages bowel movements with daily stool softeners. Baseline BP is typically 110/70. 14:30: A: Patient reports a sudden onset headache, flushing, and profuse sweating above the level of injury. BP is 210/110. Heart rate is 55 bpm. Patient is anxious and restless. Suspect autonomic dysreflexia. 14:45: R: Elevate the head of the bed to 45 degrees immediately. Check for bladder distension or bowel impaction. Administer PRN nifedipine if BP remains elevated after initial interventions. Monitor BP every 5 minutes.
